Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Engineered Extracellular Vesicles in Osteoarthritis Treatment

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults diagnosed with knee OA, meeting specific eligibility criteria.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received engineered EVs, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the therapeutic potential of engineered extracellular vesicles (EVs) compared to parental stem cells in OA management.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was improvement in joint function, measured over 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Intention-to-treat analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institutes of Health.
